Name: Um dyar
Description:
A manqala game.

From Wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Um_dyar

Um dyar (enmediar, manddiaré, umdiyar, um ed-dyar) is played by the Hassaniya-speaking population in western Mauritania, for instance in Boutilimit (Trarza province) and in Moudjéria (Tagant). Hassaniya is an Arab dialect heavily influenced by Tamazigh, a Berber language, that originated in the 15th century. At this time the Yemenite Beni Hassan tribe migrated to north-western Africa and subdued the indigenous Berber tribes over a period of 300 years. Hassaniya is today spoken in the western Sahara, from Niger to Mauritania. They constitute the majority of the population in Mauritania and southern Morocco. The Hassaniya call this region Trab el Bidan, i.e. '"Land of White People", in contrast to Bilal al Sudan, or "Land of Black People". 
Um dyar is mostly played by young women, sometimes also by men. However, they do never play among themselves, just with women, for instance as a means of courtship. 
The game is played all the year, but especially on Ramadan and during the hot hours at noon time. 
Usually the holes are dug in the sand, but there are also traditional wooden boards. Some of them are made of one piece, while others consist of two halves. 
The holes are called dyar (sing.: dar, i.e. "houses, inhabited places"). The seeds are called kyétan (sing.: kyit), probably related to kyit, Hassaniya for "odd".

Rules:

The board is made of two rows of an even number of holes, between 2 and 12. 
The number of seeds which are initially in each hole depends on the size of the board. A board which numbers just four holes has four seeds in each hole. Board that have eight or twelve holes have as many seeds as the whole board numbers holes or, alternatively, just as many as one row numbers holes. Large boards which have 16 or 24 holes have initially in each hole as many seeds as a row counts holes.

Each player controls the holes on his side of the board. 
At his turn, a player takes the contents of any hole of his side of the board and sows them counterclocwise, one by one, starting in the very same hole from where he took them. 
     If you move a singleton, it is put into the next hole counterclockwise. 
If the last seed ends in a hole making a total of an even number of seeds, not greater than the initial number of seeds per hole, these seeds are captured and removed from the board. 
If you have captured, you also get the contents of the preceding holes (in an unbroken sequence) that contain an even number of seeds, not greater than the initial number of seeds per hole. 
If a player has no seeds to play with, he passes and his opponent plays again. 
The game ends when all seeds are captured. 
The player who has captured most seeds, wins the game. 
If at the end of the game a single seed remains (i.e. there has been some mistake or cheating), the players who has an odd number of captured seeds loses one seed. These two seeds (the lost one and the seed remaining on the board) are not counted.

Usually you don't play just a game, but a match. 
In the next game you start filling the holes with the captured seeds. 
The winner fills all his holes with the standard initial number of seeds. 
The loser fills all the holes he can with the standard number of seeds. If he some seeds remain, he puts them in another hole. 
     The empty holes on the loser's side of the board are refilled with sand or marked somehow. In the next game you don't play in them. 
     If the loser has not enough holes for his seeds, he reopens as many holes as he needs. 
     There is no fixed rule about the order to close or reopen the holes. Sometimes they are openend from left to right. However, it is not important. 
The winner of the match is who captures all the seeds and leaves the opponent with no holes on his side. 
If there was a couple of seeds out of game (as seen above) they are given to the first player who makes a capture in the next game."

Name: Krur
Description:
A manqala game.

From Wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Krur

Krur (crur) is a game is played by Hassaniya (Moor) people. They are a mix of Arab Beduins and Tamazigh (Berber). Their language is mostly an Arab dialect with a strong Tamazigh influence. 
Hassaniya-speaking people live in the western Sahara from Niger to Mauritania. They constitute the majority of the population in Mauritania and in the Saharian Arabic Democratic Republic. There are some in Southern Morocco, Algeria, northern Senegal, Mali, and also a few in Niger. This region is called Trab el Bidan, ie. land of white people, in contrast to Bilal al Sudan, or land of black people. 
Krur is mostly played by children. 
Usually the holes, which are called "houses", are dug in the sand

Rules:

The board is made of two rows of four holes. 
At the beginning, there are four seeds in each hole.

Each player controls the holes on his side of the board. 
On your turn you take all the seeds from any hole of your side of the board and sow them in an anticlockwise sense, one in each hole, starting in the next one. 
If you end in an empty hole, it is the end of your turn 
If the last seed lands in an occupied hole on the opponent's side, making a total of four seeds, you end your turn and this hole is captured by you. It is marked somehow. 
If the last seed lands in an occupied hole all these seeds (the one just landed plus the ones that were already there) are taken up and you keep on sowing starting in the next hole. 
You sow seeds in the holes you have captured but not in those captured by your opponent. 
You cannot start a sowing from a captured hole. 
The winner of the game is the one that, when there are no more seeds in play, has captured more than the opponent.

Usually you don't play just a game, but a match. 
On the next game you start filling the holes with the captured seeds. 
     The winner fills all his holes with four seeds. 
     The looser fills all the holes he can with four seeds. If he has some remaining seeds, he puts them in another hole, but always an even number of them, so he can retain a single seed. 
     The empty holes on the loser's side of the board are refilled with sand or marked somehow. In the next game nobody plays in them. 
     If the looser has not enough holes to put his seeds, he reopens as many holes as he needs. 
     There is no fixed rule about the order to close or reopen the holes. Sometimes they are opened from left to right. However, it is not important to the game. 
The winner of the match is the one who captures all the seeds and leaves the opponent with no holes on his side."

Name: Lahemay waladat
Description:
A manqala game.

From Wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Lahemay_waladat

Lahemay waladat ("my cow has given birth") is a mancala game widely known in the Maqalé area of southern Tigé, Ethiopia. The game was was first described by Richard Pankhurst in 1971 as Game 17. Similar games exist in Western Eritrea and Somalia.

Rules:

Lahemay waladat is played on a board of two rows of of (sic) six holes. The game starts with four stones in each hole.

The right to start the game is decided by a hand-play referred to in Tigrinya as shekut. To begin with, the two players are holding hands as in a handshake. After breaking the hold, they would either expose the first finger, last three fingers or the open hand with fingers side by side. A player who displayed his first finger defeats one with three fingers, three fingers defeats the hand, and the hand the first finger. 
On his turn a player distributes the contents of one of his holes anti-clockwise, one at a time, into the succeeding holes. 
If the last stone is sown into an occupied hole, its contents are distributed in another lap. 
The move ends when the last stone falls into an empty hole. 
Groups of three stones made during a turn belong to the owner of the row, except a group of three that was effected by the last stone in hand which is won by the player whose hand it was. The latter kind of capture, however, does not terminate the move. The player would continue to move until his last stone in hand is placed in an empty hole (in other words, the player gets a bonus move). 
The game ends when a player cannot move at his turn. The remaining stones are won by the player who could move last. 
The player who wins more threes wins the round. 
For the next round each player fills his holes with four stones from his winnings. If a player has one surplus stone, he cedes it to his opponent who can then together with his own surplus of three stones would open another hole. If each player has a surplus of two stones, their ownership is decided by shekut. Any holes that could not be filled are closed down with sand, but can be re-opened in a later round. 
The aim of the game is to close down all the opponent's holes, that is to reduce his provision to less than four stones. "

Pankhurst, R. 1971. 'Gabata and Related Board Games of Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa', in Ethiopia Observer; 14 (3). Page 173.

Name: Lamlameta
Description:
A mancala game.

From Mancala World:

http://mancala.wikia.com/wiki/Lamlameta

"Lamlameta is a mancala game played by the Konso, a people living in Central Ethiopia near the village of Olanta. It is the recreation of adult males, and to a lesser extent boys and youths. The game is played on wooden boards with seeds in the open air or, during rains, in houses or just outside them in the shelter of the roof. The name of the game literally means "grouped in pairs", a word related to lama, the numeral two in the Gallinya language. The game was first described by the ethnologue and renowned mancala games expert Richard Pankhurst in 1971.

Rules:

The board, called toma tagéga, has 2x12=24 pits (awa). Initially each pit contains two seeds known as tagéga.

At his turn a player takes the contents of one of his pits which are then sown in a counter-clockwise direction into consecutive holes. Although Pankhurst stated that the opening move starts with the hole on the player's "extreme right or more preferably penultimate right", these moves appear to be just common openings observed by him.

If the last seed falls into a non-empty hole, its contents are picked up together with the last seed, and continued to be distributed.

The move ends when the last seed is dropped into an empty hole.

It is not permitted to drop a seed into opponent's holes which contain two seeds except in the very first move. Later these holes are jumped.

If the last seed falls into an empty hole of your own facing an enemy hole containing two seeds he captures this pair, as well as any other groups of two seeds on his opponent's row.

Play comes to an end when one of the players can no longer move. The remaining seeds are won by his opponent. The player who captured more pairs is declared winner."

Pankhurst, R. 1971. 'Gabata and Related Board Games of Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa', in Ethiopia Observer; 14 (3). Page 173.

Name: Layli goobalay
Description:
A mancala game from Somalia.

From Mancala World:
http://mancala.wikia.com/wiki/Layli_Goobalay_(long_board)

"Layli Goobalay (literally: "closing the holes") is a mancala game played in Somalia. The board is dug in the ground and the pieces are dry camel dung called salo. Slightly different variants of the same game exist, among them a more simple game, which is promoted by the Somali ethnomathematician Jama Musse Jama in Italy.

The following rules were observed in 1931 by G. Marin in the area of Berbera, Somaliland, where it was (and probably still is) a favorite pastime of the Isaaq clan.

"Layli Goobalay is played on a board that consists of two parallel rows of 12 holes on each side. A player controls the 12 holes on his side of the board.

[Holes all start with 4 seeds each.]

Each move a player empties the contents of one of his holes that is not an uur and distributes one ball in each of the following holes in a clockwise direction (as observed by G. Marin).

If the last ball is dropped in an occupied hole, the player takes its contents, including the last dropped ball, and continues to distribute the balls in a clockwise direction. The move ends if the last ball is dropped in an empty hole.

If the last ball is dropped into an empty hole on the player's own side, he captures this last ball together with the contents of the opposite hole if it contains one, two, four or more balls. A move which captures nothing is called abar ("famine").

If the opposite hole contains three balls, one of these is put into the hole in which the last ball was dropped, so that each hole has two balls. These two holes now form an uur ("pregnant"), and both are owned to their creator. An uur may never be emptied by either player. Balls must be added to an Uur during the normal course of distribution. However, if the last ball is dropped into an uur, the move ends.

The game is over when one player has no legal move left. Each side then counts the balls he has captured together with the balls in his uurs and any balls remaining on his side of the board outside of uurs. Sometimes towards the end of the game the balls continue to circulate in a repeating pattern. Then the remaining balls are divided between both players as in Oware. The player who captures most balls wins."

Variant:

There is a similar game played on a 2x6 board in the south of Somalia, which is always played counterclockwise. It has special rules for matches that were first described on wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Layli_goobalay_%28short_board%29

Name: Luuth
Description:
A mancala game.

From Mancala World:

http://mancala.wikia.com/wiki/Luuth

Luuth is a mancala game, which is played by the Nuer in the far west of Ethiopia and also on the Sudan side of the frontier. It is mainly the relaxation of menfolk, young and old alike. The game is rather unusual as only multiples of four seeds are moved.

The game was first described by Richard Pankhurst in 1971 (as Game 100) who learned it from James Tut, at this time a student in Addis Ababa.

Rules:

The game is played on two rows each of seven holes called wang, literally "eye". Initially there are four seeds in every hole.

The first player starts anywhere on his row by picking up the entire contents of one of his holes. If he did so from his middle hole he could place them in any hole, either on his own side or his opponents. If he took the contents of any of his other holes, he could place them in any hole except his opponents opposite hole.

Thereafter players alternately move either in a clock-wise or anti-clockwise direction by distributing their seeds always in groups of four.


     A group of four seeds can be moved to an adjacent hole only on the same side of the board.
     A group of eight or more seeds can be distributed on the basis of four seeds per hole in successive holes on one side of the board or another. 


If the last four seeds fall in an empty hole, the player captures the contents, if any, of his opponents opposite hole. The captured seeds are removed from the board. Then the player is entitled to continue his move by picking up the contents of any of his holes with which to play.

The player gaining the largest number of seeds is accounted the winner. The game is won in a single round.

Pankhurst, R. 1971. 'Gabata and Related Board Games of Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa', in Ethiopia Observer; 14 (3): 204.

Name: Mandoli
Description:
A Greek mancala game.

From Mancala World:
http://mancala.wikia.com/wiki/Mandoli

Mandoli ("almonds") was played in the Cyclades, Greece, in the second half of the 18th and the first half of the 19th century.

A mancala game played in the Levantine was shown by the Swiss miniaturist Jean-Etienne Liotard (1702-1789) in his painting "Deux dames grecques ou franques assises sur un divan et jouant au mankala'h" (Sanguine et pierre noire (14,8 cm x 21,7 cm)), c. 1740. Later the Scottish traveller John Galt observed Mandoli on the Greek island of Hydra in 1810.

The game appears to be influenced by other mancala games played in the Osman Empire, such as Halusa and Mangala.

				
				
					RulesJohn Galt reported in 1810 the following rules:

"There is, however, a tolerably decent coffee-house; and in winter, even at present, card and chess players may be always found in it. I saw there to-day a game, which, not having seen elsewhere, I give you a description of. The Idriots call it Mandoli, or the almonds, and it is played at a board by two persons. Twelve hollows are scooped in the board, in two rows of six each: in each hollow six balls are placed, and the opponents take each a row. The game is commenced by the first player taking out the balls from any one of the hollows, and distributing them, one by one, successively, round the board. In the first round no balls can be captured, but in the second the contest becomes serious. The skill of the player consists in so managing his distribution, that his last all shall either fall in a hollow where there is only one, or three, or seven, or nine &c. which, by the addition of his ball, are made even numbers, and in consequence become prizes. If in the distribution he makes even numbers in the two last hollows, he takes the contents of both. This is considered a great stroke. The victor is, of course, he who reckons the greatest number of prisoners."

Name: Mangola
Description:
A mangala game.

From Wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Mangola_%28traditional%29

"Mangola has become in recent decades the most popular Mancala game played in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It is known from the Virunga mountains to the Sudanese border, and from Bangui (Central African Republic) to Arui near Uganda. Mangola is a new game which was developed after 1911 according to the ethnologue Philip Townshend and is now gradually replacing older games such as sombi and single lap mancala games. The game was spread by the Belgian colonial administration and military along rivers and roads and is the only mancala game played in the central basin (one of the few African regions where mancala games were still unknown in the 19th century). 
There are many local variants, probably more than 30, which have slightly different opening rules (some with simultaneous opening moves) and employ different board sizes. 
The game is played by adults on beautiful wooden boards with holes carved in the surface. Children, on the other hand, dig the board in the ground or draw it with chalk on concrete. 
It is played by both sexes, but more often by women. 
The following rules were reported from the capital Kinshasa by Suzanne Comhaire-Sylvain in 1952.

Rules:

Mangola is a two players game. 
It is played on a board made of four rows of eight holes. 
At the beginning each hole has two seeds.

Each player controls the two rows closer on his side, and only moves on these two rows. We will call the row closest to him outer row and the other one inner row 
Players take turns to move. 
The first move of each player is a special one: they redistribute the seeds by taking the contents of one hole and putting it into the next, and so one, until your side of the board is checkered with holes containing 4 seeds and empty holes.

The second move of each player must begin from the left- or right-most hole of your outer or inner row. 
At your turn you take all the seeds from a hole on your side that contains at least two seeds and put them, one by one, in the following holes, in an anticlockwise sense. Singletons cannot be moved. 
If the last seed is dropped in an empty hole, you move it to the next hole and your turn ends. 
If the last seed falls in a non-empty hole, you take its contents including the last distributed seed and keep on sowing. 
If the last seed falls in a non-empty hole of the inner row, and the two opposite holes of the opponent contain seeds, you take the contents of your hole, including the seed just dropped, and the contents of both opponent's holes, and begin the next lap from the hole following the last empty hole (the same from which you began the last lap that effected the capture). 
When one player cannot move (his side of the board is empty or contains only singletons), he has lost the game."

Name: DracoKrak Chess
Description: DracoKrak Chess is a boardgame that is essentially Chess unleashed. The core system allows players to create various pieces, play on a bigger board, have multiple players and more. The fantasy element is strongly emphasized while keeping the abstract game play of Chess. So now, you can play Chess with interesting pieces such as The Cyclops, Ninja War Lord, Succubus, and the Fairy. Expansion for this game is unlimited and at an extremely low cost as players can do everything in a homemade fashion. Unlike normal Chess, the game play is not as competitive and has a much more laid back atmosphere.

Name: Zigoto
Description:
Not easy for a Zigoto to live on Earth!! The extraterrestrials must understand that a television is not a pillar. These Zigotos are zany!!!

The aim of the game is to be the first Zigoto to assimilate a certain number of different human behaviors

Name: The Modern Orchestra Game
Description: This is a turn of the century card game. There are 24 cards that show different types of orchestra instruments. Wood Wind, Brass, Percussion and Strings are included. Object of the game is to answer musical questions posed on each of the cards.

Name: Volley
Description: Milton Bradley Action Volleyball Game. Advertised on the game box as a "Fast action random shot game".  The object is of the game is to hit the ball (attached to a pendulum type device) back and forth over the net. If you fail to return the ball your opponent scores a point.

Name: Freddy Frog
Description: This game was published by Milton Bradley in 1910.   This game comes with a   spinner and 4 wooden markers. Game instructions are printed on inside of lid, and the gameboard is on inside of box. The object of the game is to jump the Frogs from the shore, across the lily pads to the Sunshine Log at the opposite end of the board.

Name: Pearl Fisher
Description:
As listed on FunAgain.com:

Pearl Fisher is an elegant synergy of abstract strategy and memory games. The "pearls" are glass marbles. Move pearls and cover them with shells. Can you uncover the right color of pearl?

Two game boards in one -- square grid on one side, a hex grid on the flip side. Beautifully handcrafted 11½-inch boards are laser-engraved. Three different game themes and three solitaire challenges.

Contents:
--3 sets of 9 pearls
--9 shells
--felt slipcase

Name: Harpoon Naval Review 2000
Description:
From the Clash of Arms Games web
Harpoon Naval Review 2000 provides detailed scenarios that allow you to explore conflicts in the Taiwan Strait, the Indian Ocean, South America, the Mediterranean, and the Baltic. Harpoon Naval Review 2000 also includes articles on current naval events around the world, optional rules for logistics and endurance, along with ship and aircraft forms for the scenarios.

Harpoon Naval Review 2000 has 72 pages, containing:

* Articles on:
      The Navies of South America
      A Royal Navy for the 21st Century
      38 Ship Forms- Littoral Warfare

* 4 Aircraft Forms

* Optional Rules for Naval Logistics, Repairs, and Endurance

* TEN Detailed Scenarios

* 5 Stand-alone:
      Blow in the Baltic - Russia vs. Germany
      Assault on a Queen - Libya vs. Great Britain
      Conflict of Interest - India vs. China and Pakistan
      Fish Wars, Round 2 - Canada vs. Spain
      Action in the Adriatic - NATO vs. Yugoslavia

* 5 Theme Related:
      One China - 3 concerning China vs. USA and Taiwan
      The Second War of the Pacific - 2 with Peru and Bolivia vs. Chile

Name: Duel in the Dark: V1-Bunker
Description:
This is an expansion for Duel in the Dark: Baby Blitz. It adds another asset counter for the Germans, the V1 launch bunker at St. Pol.

From the card:

V1 Bunker
Wasserwerk 1 St. Pol

The Wasserwerk (WW) marker protects a V1 from Mosquito interception. The marker is placed on the map when the other German fighters are placed on the game board - not secret placement. One may be placed on the board in any legal hex. Placement of the WW marker costs the German player 1VP. The effect of the WW marker prevents the Mosquito(s) from intercepting the V1 on the turn/in the hex in which it takes off. The WW protects one V1 in the hex.

Der Wasserwerk Spielstein schützt eine V1 vor dem Abfangen durch die Mosquito in dem Zug in dem sie vom Hex mit dem „Wasserwerk" startet. Der „Wasserwerk" Spielstein wird offen auf dem Spielbrett platziert wenn die deutschen Jäger gesetzt werden. Der Einsatz des Spielsteins kostet den deutschen Spieler 1 SP.

Expands:

    Duel in the Dark
    Duel in the Dark: Baby Blitz

Name: Byggare Bob: Samla verktygen
Description:
Use the roundel to randomly identify tools the players may add to their player boards (toolbox) to complete the pattern consisting of tiles of tools.

First one to collect all the tools, and having placed them in the right order, wins. If all tools have been properly placed, the players have also made a picture of Bob and his friends. Turn the toolbox upside down and see if all the tiles were correctly placed.

Name: The Raiders Attack: Banana Village Minigame
Description:
The Raiders are attacking Banana village again! This time they are not going to hold back!

This is a game for 2 players where one player control the Raiders while the other controls the villagers. Villagers set traps and save routes, while Raiders maneuver through the map, both players collect points according to their strategy and player with the highest points is the winner.

Name: Porto Seguro
Description:
Porto Seguro was specifically designed to learn about the Belgian social security system. A system where everybody obligatory contributes taxes to a fund that redistributes that money to those who need it most.

The game mimics this system as players start out at different wealth-levels and have to contribute, by sharing their wealth with other players. Players who do so get rewarded, players who don't get punished.

The game is designed so that when you're wealthy you have more options, but you have to contribute more. When you're poor you have fewer options but get supported by the game's system.

At the start of each turn players receive their income in the form of cards. Some of those go into the social security system to support the less fortunate players.

Players can trade the remaining cards with each other. Those involved in the trade can perform the action on the card. Actions involve moving up or down on the social ladder.

The cards have differently colored background and the final goal is to get seven cards of the same color.

The game is lightened up by using a theme that is not directly related to the matter. Players are boat owners with boats ranging from a luxury yacht to driftwood.

Name: What Can You See?
Description:
A collection of detective games
Through play, close observation is stimulated and vocabulary broadened.

The twins Tony and Tina have a superb idea; together with their three friends they want to found a secret society. The secret society’s goal will be to resolve exciting cases and become authentic detectives. On tender hooks the five have their first secret meeting in the tree house.

Contents
1 game board printed on both sides (farm/city)
5 magnifying glasses
19 decorations
30 search cards “farm” (green backside)
30 search cards “city” (blue backside)
1 hour-glass
1 die with symbol
1 set of game instructions

Name: Planet der Sinne: Fühlen
Description:
A collection of educational games by the HABA editors. Games include assembling jigsaw puzzles blindfolded, matching tactile cards only by touch, and identifying traced shapes by touch.

Contents: 

    1 "Suzy Velvet Paw" figure
    1 game board
    20 tactile cards 
    2 four-part jigsaws
    1 bag
    1 blindfold
    20  wooden animals (4 each: hedgehogs, frogs, fish, cows, wolves)
    1 die
    1 poster
    instructions
    sensory information leaflet

Name: G4
Description:
An educational game to be used in a classroom environment, published in Flanders. The aim is to learn about city government and local politics.
A cityscape is built up out of roads and buildings. The buildings are sheets of thick paper that are placed upright with plastic stands.
Pupils are members of the city council, representing one of four parties. They must gain votes (represented by meeples) by answering questions on politics in Flanders, and by having their party projects accepted by a council majority.

Name: Starfall Speedway Game
Description:
From the Publisher's Description:

This is more than a simple board game. It contains 2 complete games, which can easily be tailored to your child's reading or pre-reading level. Beginning readers can learn their ABCs driving on Starfall Alphabet Avenue, and learn to read short-vowel words and high-frequency words while racing on the Starfall Speedway. Children start with letter names and sounds, and then progress to reading words, producing rhymes, or using words in simple sentences. Both games easily grow with your child's expanding literacy skills, and foster a love of reading that lasts a lifetime. You will be amazed that learning to read can be so much fun!

This exceptional game set is packaged in a sturdy, colorful box, and includes a large 2-sided game board, 3 decks of high-quality Starfall Phonics Skill Cards, a spinner, and 8 race-car playing pieces. Instructions in English, Spanish, French and Chinese are included.

Name: Raise The Ruins
Description:
In Raise the Ruins, players are priests, fresh from their trials in the Temple of Favors.  Many of Azytecal's once great temples stand on the cusp of ruin, the voices of the faithful no longer echoing throughout their halls, and the altars lay barren.  Restoring these temples is the object of Raise the Ruins.

Players vie for the blessings of the three deities and send their followers to the forgotten altars bearing offerings.  Raise the Ruins is a card driven set collection game with easy to grasp mechanics and engaging game play decisions for 3-4 players, Ages 10 and up, and plays in 45-60 minutes.

Components:
52 Offering Cards
8 Trophy Cards
12 Temple Cards
3 Deity Cards and 3 Wooden Deity Markers
2 Wooden Crest Markers
4 Favor Cards
24 Wooden Followers (6 in each color)
4 Score Cards & Wooden Markers

________________________________

Raise The Ruins will be available later this month in standard Small Box Games limited print run.  Additionally, a add on pack will be available for those already owning TEMPLE.  A downloadable version of the board for TEMPLE will also be available for downloading, and, in conjunction with the rules already available online, playing TEMPLE will be possible with a copy of Raise The Ruins

Name: Finger Soccer
Description:
From the publisher's website:

In the tradition of paper football played by millions of kids, both young and old, Zelosport has taken this same concept to the most popular sport around the world! Finger Soccer allows fans to take this great game indoors to the kitchen table where families can enjoy many more hours of entertainment, day or night, rain or shine!

Name: Formula Dé: ITALY SERIES – Palermo Marina
Description:
This is a Formula Dé track available for free download online - created by  Alessandro Crespi. 
It is a course based on Palermo City (Italy, Sicily).
You will race near Tirrenum Sea at the Marina.
This is part of a track series called ITALY SERIES.

02. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Roma Colosseo
03. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Roma Isola Tiberina
04. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Milano Castello Sforzesco
05. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Bologna Stadio Dall'Ara
06. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Palermo Marina
07. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Trieste Porto
08. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Agrigento Valle dei Templi
09. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Torino Centro
10. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Firenze Lungo Arno
11. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Commemorative Track
12. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Misano, Santa Monica

Name: Formula Dé: ITALY SERIES – Trieste Porto
Description:
This is a Formula Dé track available for free download online - created by  Alessandro Crespi. 
It is a course based on Trieste City (Italy, Friuli Venezia Giulia).
You will race near Adriaticum Sea at the City Dock.
This is part of a track series called ITALY SERIES.

01. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Bologna Centro
02. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Roma Colosseo
03. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Roma Isola Tiberina
04. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Milano Castello Sforzesco
05. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Bologna Stadio Dall'Ara
06. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Palermo Marina
07. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Trieste Porto
08. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Agrigento Valle dei Templi
09. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Torino Centro
10. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Firenze Lungo Arno
11. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Commemorative Track
12. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Misano, Santa Monica

Name: Galaxy of D
Description:
GALAXY OF D
A TWO Players hex & counter space combat game 
Fast, brutal and diceless combat !

The galaxy is randomized at the beginning of each game, so no two games are the same ! And you will constantly try to outthink your opponent (in a fun way, in our experience :) ) 
The game length is about 45-90 minutes (depends on the players). In the gameplay Galaxy of D uses almost no dice/randomizer of any kind, I think this is a very Euro game. Bad moves, and the game can end in 15-30 minutes!

1. INTRODUCTION
Once again, the Redog (red) and the Cynder (blue) come face to face to conquer a galaxy…the Galaxy of D !!
You are a space war commander who controls a small fleet of ships on the Redog/Cynder side. You spend money to buy ships, then you can move ships around to attack other ships and enemy Starbases. Also, you can take control of planets and asteroids by moving your ships to their sectors. Holding planets and asteroids is important because this gives you a steady income that can be used to buy more ships, but keep in mind that your enemy is going to be competing with you for those same resources.
If you move a Freighter to a planet, it automatically acquires cargo. Once a Freighter has cargo, you can sell it to the Spaceport. Each Freighter can carry one cargo and only Freighters can carry cargo. Just watch out for those pirates!
One last thing. In an act of sabotage, someone turned on your Starbase’s self-destruct mechanism. This means that it will gradually destroy itself, assuming that your enemies don’t eliminate you first. Really, you have no time to waste. Get to it, commander!

2. THE MISSION
Your goal is to eliminate your enemy’s Starbase while protecting your own.

Home Page: http://www.jackdgames.com

Name: Deukalion: Whirlpool of the Charybdis
Description:
This expansion for Deukalion consists of three vortex tiles that can be placed on a space near the edge of the gameboard, allowing for instantaneous travel but at the potential cost of some of your crew.

It has been a free gimmick at the Essen fair 2008.

Name: Deukalion: Theseus – Conqueror of the Minotaur
Description: This expansion for Deukalion brings the Greek hero Theseus into the game, where he can serve as a powerful warrior on your ship, fighting twice as well as normal figures. Just watch out for opponents poaching him for their own crews.

Name: Wie verhext!: Der brodelnde Theriak
Description:
This small expansion adds three special victory point cards (4, 2 and 1 point) to the game. 
A player can get the highest available card if he has at least one of any sort of potion cards.

Name: Ärger Dich schwarz!
Description:
This is an expansion for "Mensch Ärgere Dich Nicht" (Pachisi, Aggravation). It adds more possibilities to this classic game. Instead of rolling the dice you can play a card. The cards can dramatically change the game.

Expands:

    Pachisi

Name: The Magro Game
Description: From the box "The International shipping game for 3 to 6 players. You win The Magro Game by becoming the wealthiest shipowner afloat. Which is far from easy. To prosper in this game you'll have to be successful at outbidding your opponents for the most lucrative cargoes, quick at working out the most profitable routes, and adroit at running your fleet in the most efficient way. None of which is very far removed from the real thing. But then, that's what The Magro Game is all about."

Name: Joc de la Festa Major
Description:
The celebration of Vilafranca is annual and is typical of Catalonia.In the 1994 they published this game to collect money. 
The game is similar to game of goose but acclimated in the celebration.

Name: Gold Rush The Prospectors Game
Description:
This is a very simple game in which the players take turns spinning a 6-sided teetotum, each spin determining the distribution of the 10 "gold nuggets" that come with the game.

The contents of the game are the metal teetotum, nuggets, rulebook with a very short history of the California gold rush, and a canvas pouch to hold it all.

Teetotum has sides T1, T2, TA, P1, P2 and PA.

Name: Spite 'N' Malice
Description: This is a 2-deck, 2-player version of Spite & Malice with cards Ace through King, rather than Ace through Queen.  The jokers are also excluded.  It is very similar to Skip-Bo.
Families: Traditional Card Games: Spite and Malice

Name: Bakugan Attack
Description:
Unleash the power of Bakugan in a fun, fast-paced card game for the whole family!

Challenge your friends and family to a fast-paced game of Bakugan Attack!  This easy to learn card game has all the heroes and action of the Bakugan Battle Brawlers tv show.  Roll the dice to determine how many Bakugan to catch.  Use your strategy and special cards at the right time to knock out your opponents.  Use the power of your cards wisely to change the game around to your advantage.  Get the correct amount of Bakugan cards to win.  The power is in your hands!

Name: Le Cadran de Kaplan
Description:
First you put 12 cards in a circle on the board and 6 cards in the middle. Cards are chosen in accordance with symbols on there backs. On the other side there is a letter or a space for cards on the circle, and a clue for cards in the middle. Letters will make a word 6 to 12 letters long. You don't know where the beginning and the end of the word are. You must find it as fast as possible. More than 400 current French words are available.

The most impressive in this game is that the game itself creates the word! All players can play together to find it, including the player who put the cards on the board in the first place.

Each player rolls 3 d12. The roll indicates which cards are available for auction. Players can put on a card a token face back (values of those tokens are from 1 to 9).

When 3 tokens are put on a card, the value of the token is shown. The player with the highest value can look at the card.

In a second part of the game some cards are shown to all the players. Winning auctions allows the player to look for a clue card.

When a player thinks they have discovered the word he/she writes it on a paper. At the end of the game, the word is revealed. Players win victory points in accordance with the earliest correct deduction.

Name: Kumbuka
Description:
Kumbuka is a collection of different games using the tile set in different ways. The games are mostly for young children and encourage thinking and memory skills.

The games are; Pairs, Guess The Animal, Animal Caravan, Animal Party.

The fantastic art on the tiles is derived from the work of Edward Saidi Tingatinga, who drew his inspiration from the local cave art in Tanzania. Helvetas is a Swiss charitable group that supports artists in a workshop in Dar im Salaam producing Tingtinga work.

Name: Ying Yang
Description:
Ying Yang, subtitled: "A Game of Strategy for ages 8 to Adult, Game for Two", produced in Springfield, Oregon.

From the BACK of the box:

Object of the Game:
"To participate in moving the place markers ('pawns') across the board until one player is successful in moving his place marker into his winning corner."

Contents: 

    The box of which contains the instructions on the back of that.
    An illustrative tri-folded half-sheet of examples of plays.
    2 Sets consisting with a red or green pawn and matching 4-d6. 
    A Ying Yang vacuform shallow tray/board to conduct playings upon with this.

Name: Follow That!
Description:
From the back of the box:

Prepare yourselves! An exciting contect is about to begin, and the arena is yours.  The challenge?  FOLLOW THAT!, a pastime almost as amusing for spectators as it is the players in the fray.

A word game which tests your reflexes and your memory, FOLLOW THAT! contains 600 categories covering just about every subject under the sun.

EXAMPLE: The subject is Popular Movie Quotes.  Someone calls out "Frankly my dear, I don't give a damn" - if you follow up with "probably the best lager in the world" - you'll get the thumbs down for using a non sequitur, (something that simply doesn't follow).
If you'd said "Make my day" you'd be laughing.

A truly democratic game for three or more players (the more the merrier), the idea of FOLLOW THAT! is to stay in the fray and score more!

For 3 or more players Age 7 to adult.

Name: Génies en herbe
Description:
A trivia board game based on the popular TV show "Génies en herbe".  (aired on Société Radio-Canada)

Has many of the same mechanics of the TV show.

Covering many fields of knowledge and containing over 3500 questions written by one of the TV judges.

Content:
1 board game
1 black cards holder
6 divider cards
1 dice
1 Rulebook
1 box with 750 question cards
10, 20 and 100 points money bills
1 hiding-card
6 playing tokens

Game goal:
Victory goes to the first player to reach the agreed upon point limit (ex: 300 points, 500 points).

Name: "Canberra visitor" a game about our National Capital
Description:
"Canberra visitor" The Capital board game

This game is intended to provide an enjoyable and stimulating way of learning about Australia's National Capital.  It is also an effective medium for teaching, learning and practising a range of skills.

The board is based on a scale map of the city showing its geographical features, the major road system and the location of 40 places of interest.

Players move tokens along a road system, determining their rate of progress by trying to avoid strategically placed penalty spots and chance spots.

Sketches and detailed information of the 40 places are given on large playing cards and players are exposed to daily life situations in the capital through the use of chance cards.

Detailed instructions for 4 games, each of increasing complexity are clearly presented in a small booklet.

Name: New World Disorder: CyberZone
Description:
Cyberzone is a cybernetic rules add-on for New World Disorder: urban skirmishes in a dark future, the easy-to-learn, miniatures-based tabletop game that takes place in a very near and very dystopian future.

Enter the CyberZone, a prison for the hordes of illegally-mechanized citizens that once plagued the outside world. These freaks are even more deadly than the crews that battle it out for control in Angel City. The residents of the CyberZone take advantage of the power that their cybernetics provide—from stronger limbs and better vision to mounted weapons and sub-dermal armor. Embrace the metal!

Available in PDF format and as a Printed Set with full-color paper miniatures.

Expands:

    New World Disorder: urban skirmishes in a dark future

Name: Zombies Want Fluffy
Description:
Zombies Want Fluffy™ is an exciting two-player head-to-head board game where shambling undead horrors meet Fluffy, the adorable family dog. Each game takes 20 to 60 minutes to play, and features a tense, surprise-filled chase mechanic.

The story thus far... Fluffy has had a lot to drink and is looking to “visit” a tree on his way home late one night. And he’s found his mark -- a beautiful, secluded tree right there in the back corner of the cemetery. Unbeknownst to poor Fluffy, the cemetery is filled with man-eating, er..., dog-eating zombies who just woke up for a midnight snack. Fluffy is gonna be that snack if the shambling menaces having anything to say about it. Can you help Fluffy race to freedom (and relief!) before his bladder explodes or he becomes zombie chow?

A serious game is at the heart of this absurd premise.

Name: The Oblivion Pack
Description:
This 12-scenario pack was released by Fanatic Enterprises to utilize the new armies made available by the ASL module Armies of Oblivion.  The scenarios all include armor and the armies of Bulgaria, Croatia, Romania, Hungary or Slovakia.

FE 116 Bad Neighbor Policy: A small scenario set on boards 3 and 49. The scenario features a March 1939 border action featuring a small Slovakian combined arms force attacking a small Hungarian force. This is nice tourney sized scenario.

FE 117 Sanok Action: This scenario is set on boards 48 and 2. This is a medium sized scenario set in the opening days of Barbarossa. The scenario features a dug in Russian force holding off a German-Slovakian force that needs to capture some pillboxes.

FE 118 Zaporhze Island: This is another tourney scenario set on boards 47 and 8. Some dug in Russian defenders defend a stream crossing and try to hold some buildings against a infantry armor Hungarian force.

FE 119 The Face of War: During the Crimea Campaign, this scenario features the Rumanians attacking some dug in Russians supported by late arriving armor. This scenario is set on boards 19 and 16. This is your typical attack counterattack situation.

FE 120 Nasty Business: Much of the time Axis Minor troops were performing security services. This scenario set on boards 19 and 49 features a small partisan screening force attempting to delay rear echelon Slovakian troops from attacking the buildings on board 49 from a force of partisans set up on 49. This is a medium sized scenario.

FE 121 Allies in a Few Days: This one is set on boards 40 and 42. This is a meaty scenario featuring a river crossing with a twist. A dug in Russian force tries to keep a Rumanian force from crossing the river but the twist is that the Rumanians have troops popping out of the ether behind their lines. This action represents a situation where the Russians had broken through the Rumanian lines and reached a river. The Rumanian 1st Armored Division was tasked with counterattacking but the Russians were still dealing with bypassed units.

FE 122 Slovakian Slugfest: This one is set on boards 40 and 50. The Germans are attempting to squash the Slovakian Uprising. The Germans are attacking down these boards against Slovakian armor and infantry supported by partisans. Some unique set up conditions give this good replay value.

FE 123 Enemies All Around: The Bulgarians show up in this scenario. A small rear echelon German unit is surrounded. The Bulgarians have to destroy their vehicles. This scenario is set on boards 24 and 50.

FE 124 Paulis Detachment: This is a very meaty scenario featuring the Hungarians fighting the Rumanians on boards 49 and 22. A dug in Rumanian force tries to hold off an strong Hungarian attack.

FE 125 Lessons Learned the Hard Way: Here is a quick playing tourney scenario set on board 48. A small German force sets up HIP and tries to ambush a Bulgarian Reconnaissance unit. This should be a good one for lots of play with a great deal of replay potential.

FE 126 Path to Retribution: The Yugoslavian armored brigade shows up in this one as they try to catch and destroy a German/Croatian combined arms force. This meaty scenario is set on boards 41 and 49.

FE 127 Junkyard Wars: This scenario features the Bulgarian Armored Regiment attacking a force of Germans. Both sides get substantial armor and this is a meaty scenario. This scenario is set on boards 16 and 48

Name: Blotto
Description:
From the game tube:

Blotto is a Party Game
Play it with as many people as can fit around the giant Vinyl Board.

Blotto is a Drinking Game
You drink is used as he actual playing piece.

Blotto is a Fast Moving Strategy Game
Quick to learn with noise-makers provided to hurry slowpokes.

Blotto is a Party Starter."

Think of Quoridor played with drinks?  You are trying to move your drink to the temperance zone, last one to make it there has to drink.  You have Blocks you can put up to slow your opponents down.

Name: Lion Country
Description: Lion Country is a Monopoly-esque game produced as a fundraiser for the Centre County Medical Society Auxiliary in 1983 by CPM Associates.  In this game, you acquire and expand franchises.  It uses the typical roll & move mechanic of Monopoly, but rather than buying groups of properties, you can expand almost any property by purchasing franchise discs thus expanding it.  It has a single chance-like card deck.  It is called Lion Country after Penn State's mascot.

Name: Frantic Frogs
Description: In this game you hit a 'leaf' (plastic 'flipper') which catapults your magnetic frog up a stem to try and collect metal 'bug' discs while your opponents are doing the same. It's a race to see who can finish with the most 'bugs'.

Name: Jeu des boucles
Description:
A set of 36 cardboard tiles featuring numerous paths on each, and 4 borders with ending loops.

Up to 6 players compete to build the largest loop.

The rules are close to Tantrix, but the tiles are identical to those found in the recent game Tsuro.

Name: Stop de Stropers
Description:
Springtime has come. The animals wake up in search of food. The players are forest keepers and have to protect the animals from the poachers. The poachers have hiding places, but to catch the animals they have to come out of their hiding places and can be catched. You have to work together to surround and catch them.

Every turn has 4 parts:
1. All poachers move by rolling one colour-dice. Green makes them go through the woods to the next hiding place, red through the fields and blue by boat over the water.
2. The forest keepers move one step at a time. From a flower field to a forest and vice versa. You can make an extra step if an area is already guarded.
3. You wake up two animals, they will come out of their dens, the place where you put them on the board. Ducks go into the water, boars to the forest next to the den and deers to the flower fields.
4. You may move one duck, one boar and one deer to the next area. Each area has only enough food for one animal.

Game end
When the last poacher is caught, you have won!
You lost if one animal is cought by a poacher, or if an animal has not enough food.

Name: Give and Take
Description:
From the designer:

"Give and Take is a board game one can learn in a few minutes, although mastering it may take a little longer... like a lifetime.

Simplicity and elegance with diabolical plotting and incredible depth of thought make this game worth trying.

This may be the only board game one may win even when trailing way behind.

A combination of chess, checkers and backgammon principles with a unique way of sacrificing pieces for position, Give and Take is destined to withstand the test of time."

Players start with sixteen pieces that can move one space forward or to the side, but never backwards. Pieces are captured by jumping and if a piece can capture another, it must (like ZERTZ).

If a piece advances to the opponent's edge of the board, it becomes a King and can now move any number of spaces in a single orthagonal direction. Also, if a player only has one piece remaining, that piece automatically becomes a king.

The winner is the player who captures all of his/her opponent's pieces.

Name: Sieben
Description:
Cards have a number (1-7) at the top, and a hole at the bottom. Each player starts each round with 7 cards. The starting player plays a card face up to the discard pile. In turn order, players discard a card directly on top of the discard pile, either playing hole-on-hole or hole-on-number. The sum of visible numbers must be equal to or greater than the previous sum, but no higher than 7.
- If you cannot play, take a penalty card -- turn over.
- If you discard a card and the sum is not 7, draw a card -- play passes to next clockwise player.
- If the sum is 7, set aside that discard pile and start a new one by playing another card -- your turn is over (do not draw a card).
If a new draw pile is needed, shuffle all cards already set aside.

When a player runs out of cards (plays their last card creating a sum of 7), they take 1 VP chip + 1 chip per player remaining. Play continues until only 1 player is left with cards.

With 2-4 players, the game ends after 7 rounds; with 5-7 players, play till the VP chips have all been handed out. The player with the most VP wins!

Name: Världsrekord
Description: An old game about athletics where the placers compete with eachother in up to 16 different sports, such as e.g. highjumping, racing, javelin and high jump.

Name: Missúmdàlikoi
Description:
Missúmdàlikoi is a large-unit, board war game set on M.A.R. Barker's world of Tékumel. It was published in Volume 2, Issue 1 of Seal of the Imperium, a publication of Zottola Publishing, Inc. (www.zotpub.com). The rules for the game appear on pages 132-199 of that issue.

Rules for two scenarios are included: a two-player Salarvyáni offensive into Tsolyánu and a 2-4 player Tsolyáni invasion of Salarvyá.

Name: Song of the Dwarf Lords
Description: Players represent Dwarven nobles.  Each turn you will attempt to win honor by giving the most money in the Contest of Gifts.  The winner of the Contest also gets first pick of the opportunities available for that year; lands that can increase your wealth, magical items, buildings and quests.  You must manage your gold carefully and evaluate the relative value of the opportunities based on the stage of the game and what you and your opponents have already developed.

Name: BattleTech: Chaos Campaign
Description:
Chaos Campaign rules provides an open-ended campaign framework that easily allows gamemasters and players to use a variety of published-tracks to create their own unique gaming experiences using forces of their own creation. Each track that plugs into the Chaos Campaign rules system (there are no tracks found in this Chaos Campaign book which is a free download) provides a backstory that fits into the overall campaign plot. Likewise, each track is set up as a general framework to assist gamemasters and players in creating the opposing forces and adding other battlefield effects specific to that track. In addition, using the Warchest Point System, player groups may choose what direction the campaign takes.

The Chaos Campaign rules are designed to allow players to customize campaigns from the Jihad Series of Scenario books and a new set of campaign books designed specifically for the Chaos Campaign system.

The books in this series are:

     Jihad Turning Points: Luthien fleshes out the details of the conflict surrounding this pivotal world published in various Jihad Plot Sourcebooks. Additionally, players can join one of the myriad of units fighting for control—and survival—of the Combine’s capital world. Enemies from within and without seek to cut off the Dragon’s head, while loyal samurai fight to save it.


Further books are expected to be released in the coming year.

Expands:

    Classic Battletech: Total Warfare
    Classic Battletech: Tactical Operations

Name: Treasure Chase
Description:
The game's designer emailed me a description of the game as follows:

"It’s a game of pirates, adventure, skill and skulduggery. In essence it’s a race to find the X square and discover the location of the hidden treasure. Along the way you have to collect eight various items to aid you in your expedition, but also look out for all the things which can trip you up and tunnels that can aid you in your search.

Treasure chase is a whole lot of fun with just a little element of strategy thrown in and is designed for the whole family to play almost anywhere – as there is no board. You just need a flat surface and up to 4 willing pirates!

Next year we intend to release the garden size version - perfect for the out door and the beach." This was emailed today 19 Nov 08 and so "next year" would mean 2009.

Name: BalaGwari
Description: This is a modern Manqala game with two rows of four pits each. Players start with 4 seeds in each pit and own the pits on the player's side of the board but this is one of the rare manqala games in which pieces are distinguishable, i.e., one player starts with white seeds and the other black. Sowing is anticlockwise starting in the pit adjacent to the starting pit and sowing one seed in each pit until the last seed is sown, without restriction on laps and sowing in the original pit if a sufficient number of seeds are in the original pit. Captures occur when the last seed is sown in an empty pit. That last seed and all seeds in the pits opposite it are captured. The winner is the player to capture more of the opponent's seeds and play continues until no more moves are possible.

Name: Dawn of the Rising Sun: Ship Forms
Description: 56 page booklet which includes a form for every ship class, including the Royal Navy ships, found in the data annex. All forms include both profile and deck plan. As a bonus, a CD will be provided with the information in PDF format so that it can be printed with ease.

Name: 1. FC Kaiserslautern: Das Gesellschaftsspiel für alle Fans der roten Teufel
Description:
This is a quizgame about the german football team 1. FCK. You have to answer questions on the 4 Masterball places to get the 4 cupcards. There are different actions on different places on the board, like changing your direction. A very unaspiring roll, move and answer questions game.
Interesting only for fans of the Red Devils (= 1.FC Kaiserslautern).

Name: Match 'N Stack Race Game
Description:
From the Box:

- Exciting three dimensional board game features molded plastic tiles with simple words and pictures.

- Great action as players "Match and Stack" word tiles on their own section of the board.

- Kids learn word, letters, objects, and test their memories all while having a good time!

Name: Warhammer 40,000 Compilation
Description:
The second collection of articles from White Dwarf for Warhammer 40,000 (the first was the Warhammer 40,000 Compendium). This book introduced the Grey Knights, Chaos Terminators, the modern Eldar (including Aspect Warriors and Craftworlds), Genestealer Cults and a few odds and ends to Rogue Trader.

This book signaled the direction the game and background was to take for the next several editions, including the current 5th edition.

Expands:
Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader

Name: Formula D: The "Shortcut"
Description:
This little expansion only needs to be printed out and added on Formula D’s board. It adds a bit more chaos to a track already has more than its fair share.  The "Shortcut" allows the driver to cut the corner short and potentially gain a big lead.  Watch out though, the gates may not be open and you may let your competitor through instead!

Expands:

    Formula D

Name: Ground Zero
Description:
From the website:

"The Game that allows you to sense the hypocrisy of the New York Politician or the embrace what it means to stare treachery and adversity head on as a Rescue Worker. With the roll of each dice sense the tenacity of a First Responder, even while being used as a political pawn."

Name: Global Ody-See
Description:
Global Ody-See is a three-dimensional (3-D) travel game designed to teach people about the world, its natural features, nations, people and their culture. Our first version will be a traditional board game but it will be special in many respects. The game uses beautiful satellite imagery and players can choose to travel along realistic 3-D routes between places of interest using different transportation modes.

Watch it being played: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dsx8nP6m0KY

Name: DragonRaid
Description:
"The exciting new RPG adventure for courageous Christians."

"DragonRaid is an exciting experience in adventure simulation. More than just a game, it offers hours of enjoyment while teaching participants to resist sin, counter deceptive arguments, memorize Scripture, and build moral and spiritual character."

The boxed set includes the following items:

     Rules & Instructions Cassette Tape
     New Player Briefing
     DragonRaid Rule Book
     LightRaider Handbook
     Adventure Master Manual
     Character Sheets
     2 Battle Grids
     Character Cut-outs
     Dark Creature Cut-outs
     NPC Cut-outs
     Dice Set (Two StarLots, One Shadow Stone)
     Adventure #1 ("The LightRaider Test")
     Adventure #2 ("Rescue of the Sacred Scrolls")
     Adventure #3 ("MoonBridge Raid Trilogy," Part 1)


Ages 12 and up.

Name: To The Top
Description: To The Top is a game where you try to top a victory ascension chart through Bluffing, voting and Co-operation. Voting is the main form of ascension through the chart however more people voting for a single item can have adverse ascension consequences. Through moderate co-operation ascension is guaranteed.

Name: What belongs where?
Description:
A game derived from Picture Bingo featuring Playmobil toys. It takes the boards from Bingo, but the pieces are in puzzle-shapes. This adds the ability to try and recognize the overturned pieces from their shapes.

The rules include a variety of other games using the pieces included. This includes guessing and memory games.

Name: Warhammer 40,000 Vehicle Manual
Description:
From the back of the rules:

"The Vehicle Manual adds an exciting new dimension to your Warhammer 40,000 games. It updates and expands the vehicle rules from the Warhammer 40,000 rulebook, and allows you to use any of the model vehicles produced by Citadel Miniatures for Warhammer 40,000 in your games"

Along with the Battle Manual the precursor to Warhammer 40,000 2nd edition. Included a 32-page rulebook  and 30 "Datafax" sheets for various vehicles in the game.

Also included the transparent "vehicle targeting grid" which was truly a unique piece of GW game development.

This was the last book for 1st edition.

Expands:
Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader

Name: Agente Secreto
Description:
A deduction and logic game.
Two countries have sent their best agents in a secrete mission. Your goal is to discover which mission and which agent was sent by the other player.

Name: 1808: Guerra de la Independencia
Description:
Components: 
•    One 18 x 24 map 
•    192 Counter 
•    One Rulebook 
•    Two Scenarios

Time Scale: 10 days
Map Scale: 35 km.
Unit Scale: Division / Brigade

The Peninsular War is set in Spain and Portugal during the Napoleonic wars. Year: 1808.

The hex map represents a map of Spain and Portugal with most of the major towns and cities represented.

One player takes the role of the French whilst the other plays the allies (Britain, Spain and Portugal).

Name: Formula Dé: ITALY SERIES – Agrigento Valle dei Templi
Description:
This is a Formula Dé track available for free download online - created by  Alessandro Crespi.
It is a course based on Agrigento a famous tourist place (Magna Grecia Temple Valley).
You will race near ancient Greek temples, inside history.

This is part of a track series called ITALY SERIES.

01. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Bologna Centro
02. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Roma Colosseo
03. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Roma Isola Tiberina

Name: Formula Dé: ITALY SERIES – Torino Centro
Description:
This is a Formula Dé track available for free download online - created by  Alessandro Crespi.
It is a course based on Torino City (Italy).
You will race near Mole Antonelliana and ancient Castles inside the city.

This is part of a track series called ITALY SERIES.

01. Formula DÃ©: ITALY SERIES â€“ Bologna Centro
